questions.question: Question 1: Match the following conditions with their most commonly involved sites.
questions.explanation:
The most common sites of the following conditions are: A true diverticulum is a blind outpouching of the alimentary tract that communicates with the 
lumen and includes all three layers of the bowel wall. The most common true diverticulum 
is Meckel's diverticulum. It most commonly occurs in the ileum. It occurs as a result of the failed 
involution of the vitelline duct, which connects the lumen of the developing gut to the yolk sac. The following image shows a Meckel's diverticulum. Condition 
Site 1. True diverticulum

A. Terminal ileu 
m 4. Polyps 
C. Colorectum 1039 
Sold by @itachibot On the other hand, false or acquired diverticula either lack the muscularis entirely or have an 
attenuated muscularis propria. Though Crohn's disease most commonly occurs in the terminal ileum, it may occur in any area of 
the GI tract. Polyps are most common in the colorectal region. They can be sessile (without stalk) 
or pedunculated (with stalk). Intestinal polyps can be classified as non-neoplastic or neoplastic in 
nature. The nonneoplastic polyps can be further classified as inflammatory, hamartomatous, or 
hyperplastic. The most common neoplastic polyp is an adenoma.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?

options.a: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.explanation:
Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel 
wall. During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to the rectum. The 
enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells. In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the 
development of a distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner (submucosal) and the 
Auerbach (myenteric) plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment. As a result, there is a lack of coordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional 
obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of the intestine proximal to the affected segment, 
leading to congenital megacolon. Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of 
ganglion cells in biopsy sections. 1040 
Sold by @itachibot Some conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include: • Chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells • Visceral myopathy • Obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture • Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis • Functional psychosomatic disorders

questions.question:
Question 3: A male infant, with a history of not passing meconium, presented with abdominal distension 
2 days after birth. Barium enema showed marked colonic dilation above a narrow segment in 
the sigmoid region. A biopsy specimen from the narrowed region demonstrated absence of 
ganglion cells. This disease may be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. It is associated with Down's syndrome. Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. 10% of all cases occur in 
children with Down's syndrome. The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum 
produces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of the 
affected bowel and proximal dilation. The absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment in 
biopsy confirms the diagnosis. 1041 
Sold by @itachibot Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Down's syndrome include: • Duodenal atresia • Annular pancreas • Hirschsprung disease Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) include: • Meckel's diverticulum • Malrotation Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) include: • Omphalocele • Incomplete rotation of the colon • Meckel's diverticulum

questions.question: Question 4: What is the most common site of volvulus?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of volvulus is the sigmoid colon. The twisting of a loop of the bowel about its mesenteric point of attachment is termed volvulus. 
Segments involved in volvulus in the decreasing order of frequency are: • Sigmoid colon • Cecum • Small bowel • Stomach • Transverse colon 1042 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia is the colon. Intestinal segments at the end of their respective arterial supplies are particularly susceptible to 
ischemia. These are termed watershed zones. These include: • Splenic flexure - where the superior and inferior mesenteric arterial circulations terminate • Junction of sigmoid colon and rectum - where the inferior mesenteric, pudendal, and iliac 
arterial circulations end

questions.question: Question 6: Campylobacter infection can result in all of the following complications except:
questions.explanation:
Aplastic crisis is associated with parvovirus infection, not Campylobacter infection. Campylobacter infection can cause: • Reactive arthritis, primarily in patients with HLA-B27 • Erythema nodosum • Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) Molecular mimicry has been implicated in the pathogenesis of GBS because serum antibodies to 
Campylobacter jejuni lipopolysaccharide crossreact with peripheral and central nervous system 
gangliosides.

questions.question:
Question 7: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient with 
watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis? 1035 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of 
mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. 
This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis. 1043 
Sold by @itachibot In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile 
overgrowth. Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are: • Antibiotic use • Advanced age • Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers • Immunosuppression

questions.question:
Question 8: A 30-year-old man presented with loose stools and right lower abdominal pain for the past 6 
months. Endoscopy was done which showed skip lesions with a cobblestone appearance. 
Histopathological examination showed aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses. Which 
of the following genes is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
1044 
Sold by @itachibot The given scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease. It is strongly associated with mutations in the 
nucleotide oligomerization binding domain 2 (NOD2) gene. Crohn's disease occurs due to the host response against microbes. NOD2 encodes an intracellular 
protein that binds to bacterial peptidoglycans and activates the NF-B pathway. Antibodies 
against the bacterial protein flagellin may be seen in NOD2-associated disease. Other Crohn's disease-related genes are autophagy-related 16-like (ATG16L1), and 
immunity-related GTPase M (IRGM), which are critical for cellular responses to intracellular 
bacteria. Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect all parts of the GIT. 
The following microscopic changes may be seen: • Aphthoid ulcerations • Focal crypt abscesses • Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of the bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, 
peritoneum, liver, and pancreas Note: Ulcerative colitis-associated genes are ECM1 and HNFA.

questions.question:
Question 9: An endoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with lower abdominal pain and 
severe diarrhea. Which of the following is not associated with this condition? 1036 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario along with cobblestone appearance on endoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's 
disease. This condition is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, not primary biliary 
cirrhosis. Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include the following: • Uveitis • Migratory polyarthritis • Sacroiliitis • Ankylosing spondylitis • Erythema nodosum • Clubbing of the fingertips • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (less frequently than ulcerative colitis) • Cutaneous granulomas form nodules referred to as metastatic Crohn's disease (a misnomer since 
there is no cancer)

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following gross findings would you see in the resected bowel segment of a 
patient with ulcerative colitis?
questions.explanation:
In ulcerative colitis, regenerating mucosa often bulges into the lumen to create pseudopolyps and 
the tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges. Features characteristic of ulcerative colitis are: 1045 
Sold by @itachibot • Proctocolitis/ backwash ileitis • Mucosa and superficial submucosal involvement • Broad-based ulcers • Pseudopolyps and mucosal bridges • Toxic megacolon Note: Granulomas, strictures, and mural thickening are features of Crohn's disease.

questions.question: Question 11: p- ANCA is positive in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Henoch-Schönlein purpura is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the small 
vessels, not p-ANCA. The following conditions are positive for perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies 
(p-ANCA): • Ulcerative colitis • Crohn's disease • Churg–Strauss syndrome • Microscopic polyangiitis Antibodies

questions.question:
Question 12: A pathology resident notes flask-shaped ulcers in an intestinal biopsy sample. This is 
characteristic of infections caused by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Flask-shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis, which is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. It most often affects the cecum and ascending colon. Parasites may also penetrate splanchnic 
vessels and embolize to the liver to produce amoebic liver abscesses. Image showing flask-shaped ulcers of amoebiasis: 1046 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: In TB, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers). Option B: In typhoid, ulcers are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers). Option C: Ulceration is not a feature of giardiasis.

questions.question: Question 13: Microscopic colitis encompasses which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Microscopic colitis encompasses two types of disorders - collagenous colitis and lymphocytic 
colitis. Lymphocytic colitis shows a strong association between celiac disease and autoimmune diseases, 
including Graves disease and rheumatoid arthritis. These idiopathic diseases both present with chronic, non-bloody, watery diarrhea without weight

Question 14: A 19-year-old boy with suspected acute appendicitis underwent laparoscopic appendectomy 
and the resected specimen was sent for histopathological examination. Presence of which of 
the following is considered confirmatory of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis of acute appendicitis is confirmed by the presence of neutrophilic infiltration of 
the muscularis propria. 1047 
Sold by @itachibot Surgical exploration is done when clinical suspicion for appendicitis is high but imaging studies 
are negative, nondiagnostic, or unavailable. In such situations, appendicitis can only be diagnosed 
intraoperatively or pathologically. 1048 
Sold by @itachibot Large Intestine - Neoplastic Conditions
